title: Quiz 1: Medicine FQE Feb 2025
description: Final Qualifying Examination from February 2025 covering Clinical Medicine and Surgery. Includes MCQs, Short Answer, and Case Study questions.

questions.question: A 29-year-old patient presents with symptoms of frothy urine, facial puffiness, and oedema. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: The triad of frothy urine (proteinuria), facial puffiness (periorbital edema), and generalized oedema is classic for Nephrotic Syndrome. Frothy urine specifically indicates significant loss of albumin (protein) in urine.
questions.hint: Think about what 'frothy' urine signifies regarding protein content.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents with features of slowness of movement, festinate gait, and intentional tremors. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: The symptoms described are the cardinal signs of Parkinsonism: Bradykinesia (slowness of movement), Festinating gait (shuffling), and Tremors (classically resting, though advanced cases vary).
questions.hint: Bradykinesia and shuffling gait are key indicators here.

questions.question: A 33-year-old female patient is brought with breathlessness, cough, bilateral non-tender pedal pitting oedema, and visible dilated neck veins. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: This presents classic signs of Right-Sided (or Congestive) Heart Failure: Raised JVP (visible dilated neck veins) and Bilateral pitting pedal edema, combined with symptoms of pulmonary congestion (breathlessness/cough).
questions.hint: Look for signs of fluid overload affecting both the lungs and the venous system.

questions.question: A 19-year-old college student treated for a sore throat infection a week ago presents with loin pains and haematuria. There is an associated morning facial puffiness. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: This is Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis. Key features: Sore throat 1-2 weeks prior, Nephritic Syndrome signs (Haematuria, Loin pain, Facial puffiness).
questions.hint: The history of a recent throat infection is the critical clue.

questions.question: An 18-year-old patient is brought with history of progressive headache, joint pains, hotness of the body, and loss of appetite. On examination, there is splenomegaly and a tinge of jaundice. The patient is febrile clinically with a temperature of 38°C. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: The combination of high fever, headache, arthralgia, splenomegaly, and mild jaundice (due to hemolysis) is the classic clinical picture of Malaria.
questions.hint: Splenomegaly + Fever + Jaundice in the tropics often points to a parasitic infection.

questions.question: A 40-year-old lady came to the outpatient with a history of weight loss and oral thrush. A complete blood count shows elevated WBC and reduced Hb. Peripheral blood film shows blast cells. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: The definitive finding is **blast cells** in the peripheral blood film, indicating Leukemia. While thrush and weight loss suggest immunosuppression, the blasts confirm hematological malignancy.
questions.hint: The presence of immature 'blast' cells in peripheral blood is pathological.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the Mode of Action of colchicine?
questions.explanation: Colchicine works by inhibiting microtubule polymerization, preventing neutrophil migration to the joint, thus reducing inflammation. It is not an NSAID and does not block uric acid synthesis.
questions.hint: It affects neutrophil migration, not the prostaglandin pathway.

questions.question: A 40-year-old man comes with a history of morning stiffness and pain on the knee, elbow, and shoulder joints. On examination, there is joint tenderness with no swelling. What is the expected X-ray feature in this patient?

options.text: Narrowed joint spaced and boutonniere deformities

questions.explanation: Morning stiffness involving multiple large joints suggests Rheumatoid Arthritis. Narrowed joint space (cartilage loss) and Boutonniere deformities are specific late signs of RA.
questions.hint: Morning stiffness is a hallmark of inflammatory arthritis like RA.

questions.question: A newly diagnosed HIV patient with a CD4 cell count of 50 cells/ul is allergic to sulphur. An alternative to prevent pneumocystis pneumonia would be:
questions.explanation: In patients with severe sulfa allergy who cannot tolerate Cotrimoxazole, Dapsone is the standard alternative for PCP prophylaxis.
questions.hint: This drug is a sulfone, often used in leprosy as well.

questions.question: A patient presenting with hemarthrosis and anaemia with a positive history of haemophilia in the family: which of the following results would confirm haemophilia?

options.text: Prolonged partial thromboplastin time with a normal prothrombin time and platelet
Normal partial thromboplastin time with prolonged prothrombin time and platelets
Prolonged partial thromboplastin time, prothrombin time and platelet count
Prolonged partial thromboplastin time and platelets with a normal prothrombin time

questions.explanation: Haemophilia A/B affects the Intrinsic Pathway (Factor VIII/IX), leading to a prolonged aPTT. PT (Extrinsic) and Platelets are typically normal.
questions.hint: Haemophilia affects the Intrinsic pathway factors (VIII, IX, XI, XII), which is measured by PTT.

questions.question: A 56-year-old presents with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and is sick looking. Barium swallow shows rat tail appearance. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: Progressive dysphagia and weight loss in an older adult suggest malignancy. 'Rat tail' appearance indicates irregular narrowing due to a tumor. (Bird beak = Achalasia).
questions.hint: 'Rat tail' implies a ragged, irregular narrowing, unlike the smooth 'Bird beak' of achalasia.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with pallor and fatigue. On examination, there is angular stomatitis with red beefy tongue. Which statement would be true about her management?

options.text: Folic acid can be used in place of vitamin B12
Coomb’s test can be used to determine aetiology
Oral vitamin B12 and folate once daily is recommended

questions.explanation: Glossitis (beefy red tongue) and Angular Stomatitis with Pallor are classic for Megaloblastic Anemia (B12/Folate deficiency). Supplementation is the treatment.
questions.hint: Treat the deficiency directly.

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy complains of left limb pain and weakness which was progressive until he cannot walk. Prior to these symptoms he had diarrhoea but no history of trauma. He can still control his urine and stool. On examination lower limb muscle power is at 0 grade and absent deep tendon reflex. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: History of preceding infection (diarrhea), ascending paralysis/weakness, and areflexia (absent reflexes) with spared sphincter control fits GBS.
questions.hint: Think of post-infectious ascending paralysis with lost reflexes.

questions.question: A patient with type II diabetes mellitus is brought in coma. The wife reports he has been unwell for the last one-week worsening. On examination he is unresponsive. Blood pressure is 90/60mmHg. Which statement would be true for the pathophysiology and management?

options.text: Serum ketoacidosis will be markedly elevated
Marked elevation of serum sodium levels
Vigorous rehydration while maintaining electrolyte homeostasis
High insulin levels to correct hyperglycemia

questions.explanation: Type 2 DM patients in coma usually have Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS), characterized by extreme dehydration. Vigorous fluid resuscitation is the priority.
questions.hint: In Type 2 DM coma, dehydration is usually more severe than in DKA.

questions.question: As a clinician in the casualty, a patient with acute kidney injury is brought to you. While managing the patient which of the following intervention would be considered as a priority?

options.text: Dialysis urgently as a first line of treatment mode

questions.explanation: Hyperkalemia is the most immediate life-threatening complication of AKI due to the risk of fatal cardiac arrhythmias.
questions.hint: Which electrolyte imbalance causes sudden cardiac arrest?

questions.question: A 70-year-old man presents with chronic cough >3 months, wheezing, and chest pain. History reveals he has worked as a casual in a local mining company for >35 years. X-ray features reveal consolidation with scattered opacities. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: Long-term occupational exposure (mining) + chronic respiratory symptoms + scattered opacities suggests Pneumoconiosis.
questions.hint: Look at the occupation: Mining involves dust exposure.

questions.question: The commonest type of dementia is:
questions.explanation: Alzheimer's disease accounts for 60-80% of all dementia cases.
questions.hint: It is the most publicized form of memory loss in the elderly.

questions.question: A 24-year-old lady with a 3-day history of diarrhoea and now blood stained, she has had similar episodes before for the last 5 years, but not as severe. Stool for ova and cyst is negative, colonoscopy revealed some ulcers on the colon. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: Chronic bloody diarrhea with relapse/remission, negative parasites, and colonic ulcers suggests Ulcerative Colitis.
questions.hint: Chronic inflammatory condition affecting the colon with ulcers.

questions.question: The movement disorder associated with Rheumatic fever is:
questions.explanation: Sydenham's Chorea is a major criterion for Rheumatic Fever.
questions.hint: Think of 'St. Vitus Dance'.

questions.question: Which of the following is a secondary cause of Nephrotic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Diabetic Nephropathy is a secondary cause (caused by systemic Diabetes). The others are primary glomerular diseases.
questions.hint: It is a complication of a common systemic metabolic disease.

questions.question: A 35-year-old shopkeeper presents with history of cough productive of yellowish sputum, pleuritic chest pain, and fever. He is HIV negative with no previous history of admission. Which organism is identified in this case?
questions.explanation: This is typical Community Acquired Pneumonia (CAP). Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause.
questions.hint: The most common bacterial cause of typical pneumonia.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presenting with heat intolerance, excessive sweating and weight loss; examination reveals goitre. The most likely Ophthalmic finding would be:
questions.explanation: Signs of Hyperthyroidism (Graves' disease). Eye signs include Lid Retraction and Exophthalmos.
questions.hint: Think about the 'staring' appearance in Graves' disease.

questions.question: A 17-year-old boy presents with tremors, palpitations, and chronic fever. On examination there is associated flank pains. Laboratory results reveal elevated adrenaline and noradrenaline levels. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: Phaeochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor causing the triad of headache, sweating, and palpitations.
questions.hint: Tumor of the adrenal medulla secreting catecholamines.

questions.question: The following is TRUE in regard to the pathophysiology of Conn's Syndrome.

options.text: Excess aldosterone stimulates excretion of potassium by the kidneys
Excess cortisol stimulates elevation of blood pressure
Reduced aldosterone causes reduced sodium excretion by the kidneys
Reduced aldosterone causes hypotension risking coma in the patient

questions.explanation: Conn's Syndrome (Primary Hyperaldosteronism) involves excess aldosterone, which increases Sodium reabsorption and Potassium excretion.
questions.hint: Aldosterone saves Sodium and kicks out Potassium.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the clinical correlation and parasitaemia in malaria classification?

options.text: Levels of ≤100 parasites/UL are likely to be asymptomatic in individuals living in endemic or non-endemic regions.
Levels between 10,000-50,000 parasites/UL carries an increased mortality and is considered hyper parasitaemia.
Maximum parasitaemia for P-Vivax and P-Ovale should be 10,000 parasites/UL
Levels >10,000 parasites/UL are likely to be asymptomatic in endemic regions.

questions.explanation: Very low parasitemia can be asymptomatic. Hyperparasitemia is typically >100,000/µL.
questions.hint: Low parasite counts are often asymptomatic.

questions.question: Which of the following are causes of Alopecia?

options.text: Oral contraceptives, ovarian tumours, pituitary oedema

questions.explanation: Thyroid issues, nutritional deficiencies (Zinc), and hormonal changes (OCPs) are common causes of hair loss.
questions.hint: Look for thyroid and nutritional causes.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the lesions seen in psoriasis?

options.text: Small discrete flat-topped papules that may coalesce to form scaly plaques
Well circumscribed erythematous papules/plaques covered with silvery scales
Diffuse erythematous papules/plaques that are self-limiting

questions.explanation: Plaque Psoriasis is characterized by well-demarcated red plaques with silvery-white scales.
questions.hint: Key words: 'Silvery scales'.

questions.question: Oliguria is clinically defined as:

options.text: Urine output of < 1000mls in 24 hours in an adult
Urine output of < 500mls in 24 hours in an adult
Urine output of < 2mls/kg/hour in an adult
Urine output of < 1ml/kg/hour in a child

questions.explanation: Oliguria is < 400-500ml/24hr in adults.
questions.hint: Less than half a liter a day.

questions.question: A traveller presents to the facility with four episodes of diarrhoea over the last 2 hours which developed after consuming food while traveling. Which organism would you highly suspect?
questions.explanation: ETEC (E. coli) is the most common cause of Traveler's Diarrhea.
questions.hint: Commonly known as Traveler's Diarrhea bug.

questions.question: A 20-year-old presents with bloody diarrhoea, vomiting, abdominal pain and fever of 38°C. You are working in a facility without a laboratory. Your antibiotic of choice would be:
questions.explanation: This is Dysentery (Shigellosis). Ciprofloxacin is the first-line empiric treatment.
questions.hint: Fluoroquinolones are used for dysentery.

questions.question: A 23-year-old man presents with painful micturition and a diagnosis of urinary tract infection. Which of these risk factors would you educate him to watch out from as you treat him?

options.text: History of UTIs in 1st degree relative, including catheter
Structural abnormalities of the urethra, indwelling catheter

questions.explanation: Sexual activity is a major modifiable risk factor for UTIs in young men.
questions.hint: Consider modifiable lifestyle factors.

questions.question: Arrange the sequence of treatment for anaphylactic shock:
questions.explanation: Adrenaline is the priority life-saving intervention and is often given simultaneously with ABC assessment, but pharmacologically it comes before steroids.
questions.hint: The most critical drug comes first.

questions.question: A patient with organophosphate poisoning presents with drooling, excess sweating, bradycardia and hypotension. These features are best described as:
questions.explanation: DUMBELS (Diarrhea, Urination, Miosis, Bradycardia, Emesis, Lacrimation, Salivation) are Muscarinic effects.
questions.hint: Remember DUMBELS mnemonic.

questions.question: A 22-year-old lady present with greenish yellow vaginal discharge, lower abdominal pains for 2 weeks. She reports it to be foul smelling. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: Trichomoniasis presents with frothy, greenish-yellow, foul-smelling discharge.
questions.hint: Greenish-yellow + foul smell is characteristic.

questions.question: The drug of choice for treatment of Treponema pallidum (Syphilis) is:
questions.explanation: Benzathine Penicillin G 2.4 Million Units IM stat is the standard treatment.
questions.hint: Long-acting penicillin.

questions.question: A patient taking anti-TB drugs reports visual disturbance with loss of red-green colour vision. What is the cause?
questions.explanation: Ethambutol causes optic neuritis (Eye toxicity).
questions.hint: 'E' for Eye.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with central chest pains, BP 80/50mmHg, pulse 110bpm, pale and sweating. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: Chest pain + Shock (Hypotension/Tachycardia) + Diaphoresis in an older male = Myocardial Infarction.
questions.hint: Classic heart attack presentation.

questions.question: A 33-year-old lady presents with unintended weight gain, hoarse voice, pulse 62bpm, and dry skin. What is the recommended investigation?
questions.explanation: Symptoms (Weight gain, Bradycardia, Dry skin, Hoarse voice) suggest Hypothyroidism.
questions.hint: Check the gland in the neck.

questions.question: A patient with mitral stenosis has a specific diagnostic sign on auscultation. What is it?
questions.explanation: Mitral Stenosis causes a low-pitched rumbling Mid-Diastolic Murmur.
questions.hint: Occurs during the filling phase (diastole).

questions.question: Which of the following investigation confirms the diagnosis of bronchial asthma?
questions.explanation: Spirometry (Lung Function Test) showing reversible airflow obstruction is diagnostic.
questions.hint: Measures air flow.

questions.question: Select five (5) common causes/risk factors for mental health illnesses:
questions.explanation: Mental illness is multifactorial, involving biological (genetics), psychological (trauma), and environmental (drugs, stress) factors.
questions.hint: Think bio-psycho-social model.

questions.question: A 33-year-old patient presents with rice-watery diarrhoea. Select the appropriate management steps:
questions.explanation: This is Cholera. Key steps: Isolation, Rehydration (Priority), Antibiotics, and Notification. Antimotility drugs are contraindicated.
questions.hint: Rehydrate, Treat, Isolate. Do NOT stop the flow with loperamide.

questions.question: For a patient with suspected Pulmonary TB, which investigations are appropriate?
questions.explanation: Diagnostic workup includes Sputum analysis (GeneXpert/Smear/Culture) and CXR. Urine is not standard for PTB.
questions.hint: Focus on the lungs and the sputum.

questions.question: Arrange the priority steps for managing Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) with shock:
questions.explanation: Fluids are the absolute first priority to restore volume. Insulin follows. Potassium is added once urine output is safe.
questions.hint: Fix the volume first.

questions.question: Match the characteristic to the type of Peptic Ulcer:

richContent.content:
FeatureDescription
Gastric UlcerPain aggravated by food
Duodenal UlcerPain relieved by food

questions.explanation: Gastric ulcers hurt when you eat (acid hits ulcer). Duodenal ulcers feel better when you eat (pylorus closes/buffer).
questions.hint: Gastric = Eat = Ouch. Duodenal = Eat = Relief.

questions.question: Select common predisposing factors for Iron Deficiency Anemia in a 35-year-old man:
questions.explanation: In men, iron deficiency is usually due to blood loss (GI bleed, parasites, piles, cancer).
questions.hint: Look for sources of blood loss.

questions.question: Order the In-Hospital Chain of Survival for cardiac arrest:
questions.explanation: Prevention -> Call -> CPR -> Defibrillate -> Advanced Care.
questions.hint: Start with spotting the problem before it stops the heart.

questions.question: A patient has Genital Herpes. Which antiviral drug is the standard specific management? (Name the drug only)
questions.explanation: Acyclovir (400mg TDS) or Valacyclovir are the standard antivirals for Herpes Simplex.
questions.hint: Starts with 'A'.

questions.question: Read the case below. Which of the following are appropriate immediate management steps?

richContent.content:
Case Study

A 19-year-old patient presents with headache, fever, and vomiting. Examination shows neck stiffness. Labs show elevated WBCs and CSF shows elevated proteins.

Diagnosis: Acute Bacterial Meningitis.

options.text: Start IV Ceftriaxone or Crystalline Penicillin immediately
Wait for CSF culture results before starting antibiotics

questions.explanation: Meningitis is a medical emergency. Isolate, start empiric antibiotics immediately (do not wait), give steroids to reduce sequelae, and notify.
questions.hint: Treat first, verify later.
